This thread is dedicated to all animals of the reptilia and amphibia classes. Topics include, but are not limited to: geckos, snakes of all kinds, frogs, salamanders, newts, turtles, tortoises, and much more. Before asking a question, do a search on the internet to see if it has been answered
Classifieds for finding breeders and products:
>morphmarket.com
>kingsnake.com
>faunaclassifieds.com
>reptilescanada.com (Canadian breeders)
>caudata.org
Most forums will have a "for sale" section on them, so look for that, especially if you have a specific herp you want. Craigslist can also be a good source for cheap aquariums, and make sure to check for any reptile expos that occur in your area.

When asking a question, make sure to include these details:
>Type and size of animal
>Enclosure dimensions
>Humidity and temperature
>Type of substrate
>The decor you use
>How often you feed
>The type of food you use
>If your animal is wild caught or captive bred
>How often you handle
>Who you bought the animal from

Other Helpful Resources
www.blackjungleterrariumsupply.com
www.joshsfrogs.com
http://www.reptilesmagazine.com
http://www.anapsid.org
http://www.hylid.clara.co.uk/caer.htm
https://www.americanmadeexotics.com/breeding-ball-pythons-article.html
http://blogs.thatpetplace.com/thatreptileblog/

com: Could animals that possess larger brain ratios than humans, gain intelligence to create a civilization with the help of experimentation and brain micro chips?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>4375855
Brain weight is a rough metric at best

What matters the most is the number of, the type of, and the organization of neurons. For example humans have high numbers of well organized spindle cells that create purposeful and efficient connections between distant layers of the brain. Dolphins have fewer and less organized spindle cells. This strongly implies an inferior form of consciousness, so despite their massive brain it's mostly just an information processor optimized for sonar with less information integration and they are about as aware of their own machinations as a chimp with a much smaller (slightly denser and more organized) brain.

Sometimes it evens out with different skills being selected for. Pig brains have a lot of fat and a little extra white matter, dog brains have more neuron density and gray matter. Pigs do not need to be taught to solve problems, but their social skills are severely lacking. Dogs need to be taught to solve problems and can do dumb shit like not even really try to solve a problem until encouraged to. What good is passing the mirror test if you sit there thinking "what if i shouldn't pass the mirror test" until someone eggs you on? However, their social skills are excellent.

In 2010, 19-year-old Sam, an avid rugby player, was drinking with Jimmy Galvin and several more of his Australian “mates” when a slug began crawling across Galvin’s concrete patio at his home in Sydney.

“We were sitting over here, having a bit of red wine appreciation night, trying to act as grown-ups. And then the conversation came up, ‘Should I eat it?’ ” recalled Galvin. “And then off Sam went and bang, that’s how it happened.”

After downing the slug, Sam became weak and complained of severe pain in his legs, according to “The Sunday Project.” Sam’s mother, Katie Ballard, told the news show that at first they worried he might have multiple sclerosis, which had afflicted her husband. But doctors said no, that wasn’t the cause.

Then Sam turned to his mother and told her he had eaten a slug, “And I went, ‘No, no one gets sick from that,’ ” Katie Ballard said. CNN has also reached out to Ballard.

Soon, however, doctors told them otherwise. Sam had developed rat lungworm disease from the infected slug.

Soon after the diagnosis, Sam fell into a coma, where he remained for 420 days, Ballard said in the Australian news report. He woke up paralyzed, unable to eat without a tube or move without intense effort. He required 24-hour care, seven days a week.

But the disease didn’t affect his mental faculties, his family and friends said.

“He’s in there, 100%,” Galvin told “The Sunday Project.” “I apologized to Sam about everything that happened that night in the backyard. And he just started bawling his eyes out. I know he’s there.”

“Sam passed away on Friday morning at Hornsby Hospital, not far from where he grew up, surrounded by 20 of those he most loved in the world,” she wrote.

“Katie tells me ‘the room was so full of love,’ ” Wilkinson said. “One of his friends there in the room continued, ‘He had his voice and he said “I love you” several times to Katie.’ “

last_replies.com:
Anons, how do you deal with G.I. Stasis?
My rabbit died of it (back in 2008 so long time ago) and I'm dreaming of getting another one (or two kek) but scared it'll happen again.
Is it too late when they get hunched up and become inactive? Is there a way of curing them of that?
Thanks in advance.
Pic not rel.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>4375159
Keep their litterbox filled with hay and/or have an unlimited supply of hay for them nearby. Try to limit too many carbs in their diet such as fruits and carrots. Keep them active, hydrated, and happy.

Treating it means a trip to the vet. It involves dealing with the bacteria in their guts, but only if its clear the issue isn’t dehydration or something else. This involves feeding antibiotics such as cholestyramine and feeding probiotics. It also involves drinking lots of water and sprinkling herbs in their food to get them to eat more (or use liquified food). There could be complications such as blockage and severe pain, which are treated with prokinetics and painkillers, at worst surgery which can be a very expensive decision and may be kinder to euthanize.

Telling someone else about your grief eases it a little, though. last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
Being around cows is usually safe if you're not an idiot and many cows love to be pet, but you shouldn't just go up to strange cows and try to get close to them. Most cattle breeds are pretty timid and can be easily spooked by unfamiliar things, and the last thing you want is for a thousand+ pound wall of muscle to run over you in a panic. Mother cows with calves and bulls are especially dangerous. But if you establish trust and show the cattle that you're not a threat, they can be very friendly and affectionate.
That said. if you want to pet a cow, you're probably best off going to a petting zoo or a farm that offers tours. That way you can be sure that the cows are acclimated to being around strange humans.
